title: Chvrches' 'Love Is Dead' is a Pop Gem
summary: The first track is a fun summer vibe with acoustic guitar and a bass line that will make you want to dance. The lyrics are about being happy in the moment and not worrying about tomorrow because you donâ€™t know what it will bring. This song is a little darker than the first with lyrics about trying to forget a bad situation, but being unable to escape it. It features a heavy drum beat and a haunting synth melody. It's about needing a body guard because the world is a scary place.

But there are still some great pop albums that aren\u2019t filled with auto-tune and EDM drops.On May 25th, the Scottish band Chvrches released their third album called \u201C Love is Dead.\u201D The synth-pop band has lots of happy vibes and catchy hooks on their new album. It\u2019s a pleasant listen but might not be what you expect if you only know them from their first two albums. The band took a left turn creatively, covering topics like technology, isolation and death rather than dancing around in your bedroom to this record.
Chvrses has gained more popularity among a different group of fans by releasing this album than they ever did with their first two releases combined. This is partially because they have expanded their audience by collaborating on songs with Haim and Bleachers recently as well as making this change in sound so now they have crossover appeal to radio listeners too!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

It\u2019s a catchy tune that sets the tone for the rest of the album, which is upbeat and optimistic. The lyrics are about being happy in the moment and not worrying about tomorrow because you don\u2019t know what it will bring. It\u2019s a great song to get you out of a funk."),mdx("p",null,"Never Hear Again"),mdx("p",null,"This song is a little darker than the first with lyrics about trying to forget a bad situation, but being unable to escape it. It features a heavy drum beat and a haunting synth melody. The chorus and vocals are catchy, with Lauren Mayberry singing about the fact that \u201Cthe world will never hear again,\u201D which is about how she doesn\u2019t want to hear about the old situation that upset her anymore."),mdx("p",null,"Deliverance"),mdx("p",null,"This song has a strong beat that makes you want to move. It has a strong bass line and a catchy synth melody. The lyrics are about rising above a bad situation and overcoming it to be stronger and more confident. The song talks about rising above the situation and turning it into something good."),mdx("p",null,"Graffiti On The Train Window"),mdx("p",null,"This tunes is slower than the others, but it has a catchy melody and has a really great message. The lyrics are about seeing something sad and wanting to do something about it but being too afraid so you \u201Cwrite it on the train window.\u201D It\u2019s about being an armchair activist and not actually making the change. The song is about realizing that you can actually make a difference if you don\u2019t stand idly by and do nothing."),mdx("p",null,"Body Guard"),mdx("p",null,"This song is a little different than the rest of the album because it\u2019s a little more aggressive and a little less upbeat. It\u2019s a little slower and doesn\u2019t have as many synths. It\u2019s about needing a body guard because the world is a scary place. It\u2019s a nice change of pace and brings a little variety to the album."),mdx("p",null,"Bottom Of The Ocean"),mdx("p",null,"This is another slower song on the album and sounds like it could be about a bad breakup. It\u2019s a little less upbeat and more somber than the rest of the record. It\u2019s about wanting to go back to a relationship that\u2019s over and wanting to \u201Cgo back to the bottom of the ocean where we started.\u201D It\u2019s about wanting to go back to a place where nothing bad has happened yet. It\u2019s a nice way to end the album with a somber tone."),mdx("p",null,"Thank you for reading."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Big Short" Is a Searing Indictment of the Financial Industry

intro.compiledSource:
var d=Object.defineProperty,c=Object.defineProperties;var g=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var s=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var i=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,a=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var h=(e,t,o)=>t in e?d(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):e[t]=o,r=(e,t)=>{for(var o in t||(t={}))i.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);if(s)for(var o of s(t))a.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);return e},u=(e,t)=>c(e,g(t));var l=(e,t)=>{var o={};for(var n in e)i.call(e,n)&&t.indexOf(n)<0&&(o[n]=e[n]);if(e!=null&&s)for(var n of s(e))t.indexOf(n)<0&&a.call(e,n)&&(o[n]=e[n]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var n=o,{components:e}=n,t=l(n,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,u(r(r({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`The film version of The Big Short hits theaters this Friday, and it\u2019s not subtle. Its tagline is \u201CThere\u2019s a sucker born every minute. But they don\u2019t grow up thinking they can be con men. They get taught to be one.\u201D And its trailer goes on to say, \u201CThe housing bubble was about to burst\u2026 And a group of misfits saw it coming. Now these unlikely heroes must band together and bring down the greedy villains who crashed the world economy\u2026 Before anyone else gets hurt.\u201D
Unfortunately, that last part is not hyperbole. The actions of unscrupulous financial engineers \u2014 colloquially known as \u201Cbankers\u201D \u2014 led directly to the Great Recession in 2008, which cost millions their jobs and homes, while triggering widespread deflation and anemic growth throughout much of the developed world for years thereafter.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

10 Rappers That Will Make You Want to Get Out on the Floor and Dance

intro.compiledSource: var c=Object.defineProperty,d=Object.defineProperties;var m=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var n=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var i=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,s=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var p=(e,t,o)=>t in e?c(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):e[t]=o,r=(e,t)=>{for(var o in t||(t={}))i.call(t,o)&&p(e,o,t[o]);if(n)for(var o of n(t))s.call(t,o)&&p(e,o,t[o]);return e},u=(e,t)=>d(e,m(t));var l=(e,t)=>{var o={};for(var a in e)i.call(e,a)&&t.indexOf(a)<0&&(o[a]=e[a]);if(e!=null&&n)for(var a of n(e))t.indexOf(a)<0&&s.call(e,a)&&(o[a]=e[a]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var a=o,{components:e}=a,t=l(a,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,u(r(r({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,"As hip-hop continues to shed its once-maligned reputation and become increasingly popular, we\u2019ve seen a related boom in mainstream rap music. More than ever before, people are listening to and talking about rappers. But with so much of the genre becoming commodified and predictable, it can be difficult for new artists to stand out among the noise. Fortunately, just because most popular rap fails to break any molds doesn\u2019t mean that the genre is completely devoid of creative talent. In fact, there are a number of rappers who have been working hard to maintain their integrity while still appealing to a larger audience. If you\u2019re ready to put on your dancing shoes and get out on the floor with one of these 10 amazing rappers who will make you want to dance:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Foster the People's 'Sacred Hearts Club' Is a Fun Ride
Haim's 'Something to Tell You' Is a Delightful Pop Album

intro.compiledSource:
var m=Object.defineProperty,c=Object.defineProperties;var d=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var n=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var i=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,r=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var u=(e,t,o)=>t in e?m(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):e[t]=o,s=(e,t)=>{for(var o in t||(t={}))i.call(t,o)&&u(e,o,t[o]);if(n)for(var o of n(t))r.call(t,o)&&u(e,o,t[o]);return e},l=(e,t)=>c(e,d(t));var h=(e,t)=>{var o={};for(var a in e)i.call(e,a)&&t.indexOf(a)<0&&(o[a]=e[a]);if(e!=null&&n)for(var a of n(e))t.indexOf(a)<0&&r.call(e,a)&&(o[a]=e[a]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var a=o,{components:e}=a,t=h(a,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,l(s(s({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`It\u2019s been almost three years since we heard new music from HAIM, the sister trio from Calabasas that burst onto the music scene in 2014 with their debut album \u2018Days Are Gone.\u2019
With their sophomore album, \u2018Something to Tell You,\u2019 HAIM continues to be optimistic and uplifting with their new music. The album is a mix of upbeat pop tracks and slower ballads that showcase the sisters\u2019 harmony and vocals. Even if you aren't a fan of pop music, it's worth giving this album a listen.
The trio had been working on this album for some time before releasing it. In September 2016, they released three singles; \u201CRight Now,\u201D \u201CNew York Excuse\u201D and \u201CSentimentality.\u201D
And after a year-long hiatus following the release of these songs, HAIM announced via Instagram in June 2017 that they would finally be releasing their second studio album (and first extended play) later that year.
Luckily for us, they stuck to their word and released the nine-track EP on Sept. 14, just in time for our listening pleasure. Here are some of our favorite tracks from HAIM's 'Something To Tell You' Album:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

"The Martian" Is a Triumph of Science Fiction

intro.compiledSource:
var l=Object.defineProperty,m=Object.defineProperties;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var n=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var s=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,r=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var h=(e,t,o)=>t in e?l(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):e[t]=o,i=(e,t)=>{for(var o in t||(t={}))s.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);if(n)for(var o of n(t))r.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);return e},d=(e,t)=>m(e,c(t));var u=(e,t)=>{var o={};for(var a in e)s.call(e,a)&&t.indexOf(a)<0&&(o[a]=e[a]);if(e!=null&&n)for(var a of n(e))t.indexOf(a)<0&&r.call(e,a)&&(o[a]=e[a]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var a=o,{components:e}=a,t=u(a,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,d(i(i({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`Ridley Scott\u2019s new movie, The Martian, is based on a novel of the same name by Andy Weir. It\u2019s about an astronaut called Mark Watney who gets stranded on Mars after his crewmates think he\u2019s dead and leave without him. This might seem as just another case of annoying Hollywood over-simplification: after all, we get so many bioengineered super-geniuses with computer uplink implants that they can become trapped in remote locations via their own stupidity. But there\u2019s more to it than that.
In both book and film, the humanity of Watney comes out in everything he does to survive: logical thinking (how can I eat this potato again?), ingenuity (I need water; how do I distill it from our CO2 filters), courage (explore the abandoned outpost), and compassion (contact my family). He also has a lot of fun with his predicament, cracking jokes through his video log and even going disco.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
